'''Quantum Content''' is a concept that describes the complexity, granularity and connectivity of the current state of content creation, consumption and curation. <ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|last=Cotsakos|first=Christos|title=The Age of Quantum Content|url=http://www.endplay.com/quantum|work=Speech|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
==Origins==
While the exact origins of the term Quantum Content remain unknown, the term was brought to relevance by [[Christos Cotsakos|Dr. Christos M. Cotsakos]] at the 2011 Gilbane Conference for the [[Web content management system|Web Content Management (WCM)]] industry. In his keynote speech, titled The Age of Quantum Content, Dr. Cotsakos defined Quantum Content as a function of [[Big data|Big Data]] and its granularity, complexity and connectivity, plus elements of serendipity and sizzle (also known as the e or error term in statistics).
'''Quantum Content''' = ''f'' {Big Data (Granularity + Complexity + Connectivity) + ''e''}<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Characteristics of Quantum Content==
Prior to the Age of Quantum Content, there were two elements: content creation and audience engagement—that focused on three areas: a creator or idea, a medium/channel and an audience. In the age of Quantum Content, Dr. Cotsakos identified three new variables that have entered the equation:
# Granularity: the ways in which a seemingly single piece of data can be viewed, processed and chopped up into various smaller pieces of data, depending on the lens, or “dimension” through which it is being viewed; # Complexity: the real-time nature of today’s content, as well as the evolution of content types, formats, and distribution channels; # Connectivity: the connections, context and unique attributes surrounding any piece of data depending on the person(s) it involves.<ref>{{cite web|title=EndPlay CEO Keynotes Gilbane Boston With Discussion On "Quantum Content|url=http://www.1888pressrelease.com/endplay-ceo-keynotes-gilbane-boston-with-discussion-on-quan-pr-354582.html|work=Press Release|publisher=1 (888) Press Release|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
==Similarities with Quantum Physics==
[[Quantum physics]] theory holds that energy comes in very small, discrete units. Each unit can have multiple characteristics. It can behave both like a particle and like a wave, depending on how it's measured.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Quantum Physics|url=http://library.thinkquest.org/3487/qp.html|work=Journal|publisher=Oracle ThinkQuest|accessdate=5 December 2011}}</ref>
Quantum content is not Big Data but rather it is a function of Big Data and its granularity, complexity, and connectivity. Big Data includes both machine- and human-generated data, and it is as granular as the tiniest elements of content – for example, whether or not a website was visited in the past day or what was said in a tweet.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cotsakos|first=Christos|title=The Age of Quantum Content|url=http://www.endplay.com/quantum|work=Speech|accessdate=5 December 2011}}</ref>
As in quantum physics, even discrete data elements in the Age of Quantum Content have multiple meanings, depending on how you look at them.
